title.narrative: CRUDAN-Food Sec. & GBV Resp. to COVID-19

description.narrative:
The Christian Rural and Urban Development Association of Nigeria(CRUDAN) is a Christian inter-denominational, not-for-profit, Non-Governmental Organization. It is a membership organization that has as its members-Churches, Christian organizations and individuals that are engaged or interested in development work in Nigeria. It has the main goal of promoting the growth of the church in Nigeriaby assisting in rural/urban development work that is part of her witness. CRUDAN serves the church all over Nigeria in Wholistic development work. CRUDAN was formed in 1990, following the merger of two Christian organizations that operated independently in the country, namely Christian Rural Advisory Council(CRAC), Founded in 1965 in the Northern part of Nigeria, and Christian Rural Fellowshipof Nigeria(CRFN), established in 1953, in the Southern part of Nigeria. Being a membership organization, the members from the general assembly that elects the board. CRUDAN has five(5) zones within the country namely, Central,Northeast, Northwest, Southeast and Southwest zones with a Zonal facilitator and Administrative Assistant for each zone. With this arrangement, CRUDAN is able to effectively cover the whole nation. CRUDAN began operation in 1991 and was officially registered by the Corporate Affairs Commission(CAC) of the Federal Government of Nigeria on 7th December 1992. Registration number 7111.
This project will build on the strengths and lessons learned from previous and ongoing programs led by Oxfam. Specifically, the action will complement the ongoing interventions ofthe EU Support to Food Security and Resilience in Northern Nigeria# (PROACT) in Adamawa and Kebbi states in northern Nigeria. The project is benefiting over 25,000 vulnerable farming households in 80 rural communities, 70% of whom will be women. These Vulnerable households, were in the verypoor and poor categories prior to Oxfam intervention in target locations of this project, and were beginning to attain comfortable positions in terms of food security and livelihoods outcomes before the COVID 19 pandemic struck. These populations are nowat risk of having their strengthened resilience attenuated as a result of COVID-19 pandemic. The project will also use the findings of the recent rapid care analysis conducted in Adamawa and Kebbi address gender based violence issues arising from the Covid 19 pandemic. The power relations which places women as the subordinate gender groups within this society, leaves the women vulnerable to GBV violence, as there is a power imbalance between men and women as highlighted by the RGA will also be addressedby this Project.
